commentBody:
Fun and challenging Friday.
Extra points for pairing "don't be evil" with "mere mortal."
Food for thought from two talented and photogenic constructors.
Well done.
PS Love the crossword printed tank top, Ms. Sinclair!
Good clues again, nice week for avoiding tons of obscure proper names.

Lots of fun tugging at a Friday puzzle 
when there are plenty of answers 
I don't know from the clues. 
Good thing this is a crossword!

Today’s crossword had me feeling like a newbie in a DAISY TROOP lost in the woods! When I hit ‘Macronutrient grouping?’, I was counting carbs and proteins, but it was just the vowels AEIOU—they really gave my brain a workout! ‘Understudy opportunities?’ had me dreaming of Broadway, but turns out I just needed some EASY A’S—who knew slacking off could be so rewarding? And ‘Field of stars?’ had me gazing into space thinking ASTRONOMY, but my horoscope must’ve predicted ASTROLOGY was the answer. By the end, my attempts to ACT clever only highlighted my own Bêtise—IDIOCY never felt so fun!

When the article has to go out of its way to explain that a clue doesn’t really make sense but it does it you just make it up, then it’s really bad.  I’m so over this new crossword editor.  Deleting this app until Shortz is back or this guy is replaced.

This was a lively puzzle with some spritely clues, including those for SANTA, EASYAS, and KIDSTABLE.  I solved it fairly steadily by jumping all around instead of trying to be methodical, only stumbling briefly.in the SW corner.

I can heartily recommend Peter Jackson’s Let It Be documentary.  It’s a wonderful look at the creative process at work, and an instructive look at the tensions in a group of talented individuals struggling with the decision to stay together or break apart.  It might have profited by some judicious editing.  The sequence at the end of the concert on the roof of Apple studio is pure gold.  Perhaps I liked it so much because I have personally always esteemed the Let It Be album (especially the stripped down Let It Be Naked remaster) very high in the Beatles canon, even above Abbey Road.  Heresy, I know.

Very tough Friday. I liked it a lot.

No Naticks and there was some nice clueing.

Very good.
It's a good one, solvable without any googling.  but I would have to read the column to understand some of the clues, like "dec" or "troop."  "Yates" was not known to me either.
If Olivia Rodrigo shows up to comment here with us mere mortals, it will be SO exciting.

Not very easy.  Not all that clever.  But still somehow pretty fun!

I liked the puzzle.  The upper left and bottom right both gave me trouble, and I never heard of "Nars, The Brand That Looks Like A Typo (TM)".  And pesto doesn't seem right; caprese should just be basil leaves.  (I'd also prefer that astrology never be referenced in a civilized forum.) 

But it was a nice tough jaunt to get through this.  A good Friday.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Ooof.  Tough puzzle.  I couldn't seem to come up with a single fill until the SE corner started to come unknotted, and then I started to like it ALLOT.  I felt I knew answers but couldn't come up with a version that would make them fit.  I finally had to accept that I am a MERE MORTAL.

Sarah Sinclair and Rafael Musa, what a clever piece of work to make such a hard puzzle really as EASY AS pie.  It was fun and so satisfying when the sea of blank squares finally started to fill up. Thank you!
Really enjoyed that one.
I don't understand 40 d. How is betraying accidental?

Deb writes, "I like to refer to [the] contest [between constructor and solver] as a tug of war." 

That's a nice analogy, and apt for this puzzle. There was enough tricky clueing that I was well down in the grid before I started entering answers. 

And when I had most of the grid filled in, the NW corner was stubbornly resistant. Although at least three of my four sisters were Girl Scouts, and my mother was a troop leader, I didn't associate Daisies with Scouts until I read the column.

Lots of fun stuff here. My favorite answer might be KID'S TABLE, which with Thanksgiving reminds me of the many holiday dinners at which I was seated away from the adults.

I mentioned this the other day, but since the puzzle includes such a witty clue for AEIOU, I'll repeat it: Someone pointed out to me that my first and last names are supervocalic. I'm sure I get some kind of prize for that, right? (Or maybe I just have a ready-made clue for AEIOU if I ever get back to constructing puzzles.)

If you liked this puzzle, you might enjoy Rafael Musa's puzzle this  week for AVCX. It's a little racier than this one, but quite enjoyable.

Thanks for the fun, Ms Sinclair and Mr Musa!

The drape specialist and I went on a blinds date.

(But our relationship is curtains.)

Hey! Isn’t Stevie Wonder the youngest artist to Debut #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 list?

The tug of war was real today😅.
Really wanted 35D to be BRAUHAUS.

Fun puzzle, I worked my way from center out with Rodrigo and Let it Be first. Until the NW corner totally messed me up. I had multiple combinations of horn and honk for the green light clue and needed help from Deb with TROOP and AEIOU to realize it was TOOTTOOT. So close to getting a Friday on my own. Are people just ready to pounce on AEIOU from experience? I don’t know how you would’ve known the multi vowel thing from that clue alone. 

I enjoyed EASYAS, TAC, and all the quoted clues. Here’s hoping Rodrigo chimes in.
That was fun! See, it is possible to have a puzzle that is not the 7:46 to Natick Central.
Personally I found this to be one of the hardest puzzles I have ever attempted to solve. It was so far beyond me it's actually kinda funny. Not my wavelength, not my trivia.

Back at ya w/ a proper noun list (not included in wordplay): SANTA, OLD NORSE, KAY, OHIO, PRADA, LEEDS, LET IT BE, DEC, ADO, HIM, TESLA, YATES, SOSA, LES

Loved the KIDS’ TABLE clue :)

I like reading the comment sections because I was able to fill this one out in on my own—my first Friday!! 

I now know how it feels like when people post their times or I search through the article for a hint that doesn’t exist and wonder how I don’t know it, but it seems to be commonplace enough to be a clue. So many times I have ticked on a hint or reveal for many a proper noun or phrase, and it reminds me of my demographic and that maybe mine is not the kind to usually solve the crossword past a Tuesday, and the occasional Thursday.

This boosted my confidence. Thank you!

The fun part of starting this at 3 AM (after seeing both Wicked and Gladiator II) was that as I got deeper into the puzzle and only the hardest clues remained, I kept getting more and more tired and losing more and more of my cognitive faculties. Managed it in 36 minutes with a Gold Star, though...
Was I the only person who confidently put down EELS for 7D?
When was the last time you spit in the dentist’s office? 😅
I loved this one! Especially KIDS TABLE!

The pitfalls of solving at 4 AM:  Confidently filled in Prado at 9D, then spent diez minutos trying to find the mistake.  Just shows to Goya.

Otherwise, fun and much faster than yesterday.
i still don't get 15a.  how is that the answer for that clue?

I know it's a favorite of puzzle constructors, but what kid would actually say ARE SO? Maybe a stage character, but 99% of those types of playground exchanges in the modern world are going to be, "Am not!"/"Are too!".

A pleasant, easy-going Friday puzzle from Rafael and Sarah.  As clued, APU gave me trouble, though in hindsight the clue was the giveaway.  Guess I don't really think of Simpson characters as toons right off the bat and was trying to think of a Loony Tunes character.
Between cookies for SANTA and PESTO for a caprese sandwich, I'm hungry.

You can tell just by looking at Sarah and Rafael that their puzzles are going to be fun.  As soon as I saw their names I was ready for a good time.  As usual, they delivered.

Great SANTA clue even though the SANTA who came to my house preferred pistachios to cookies.  We used to buy one of those little green boxes with the red dyed shells to leave out on Christmas Eve.

Deb -- I beg to differ with your statement: "...because the only contest is between each solver and the constructor." No, The "contest" is between the solver and all the tools the constructor has at her (or his) disposal (i.e. the entire internet!).

I agree with Deb that putting the puzzle aside for a while is a help.  I often feel completely stuck, but when I do come back to it I usually can see things I didn’t notice before.  This happened today a couple of times.  

So a fun Friday puzzle , Sarah and Rafael.

It’s been an usual week in puzzling. Tuesday’s result was 3 minutes longer than my average. For Wednesday, I had an “aha” moment with the revealer clue with 3/4 of the puzzle completed, and I managed to solve 5 minutes faster than my average time. Thursday, the theme fell into place for me. As a retiree, I wish theme acronym existed in business as I had many memos cross my desk for which it should have been stamped at the top and returned to the sender. And the Friday puzzle was similar with a relatively smooth solve.

TGIF!

Odd solve today.

Felt like a tough one, but was 
over in a minute!

Reeeeally wanted the Billboard answer
to end in pRODIGy,
and looking it top to bottom, 
the extra R was hiding.

Once that opened up, the music played!
Fun and… surmountable?

Thank you Sarah and Rafael!

Happy Friday all!

Another long workout for me, and had to do some look-ups but managed to fill it all in. Nice puzzle, just more than a couple of things that were never going to come to me without some crosses. But... that's what crosswords are all about. 

A couple of puzzle finds today. First - a Tuesday from November 16, 2004 by Stella Zawistowski and Bruce Venzke. Four theme answers that all had the same clue; that clue being: 
"Uh-uh!"

The theme answers: 

YOUMUSTBEJOKING
WHENPIGSFLY
THERESNOWAY
AINTGONNAHAPPEN

Those answers could be appropriate for me on a number of late week puzzles. One more puzzle find (quite amazing) that I'll put in a reply. 

...

This one felt awkward.

Wonky, even.
Just me?

*No spoilers til View All Replies please*

Strands #264
“This is the place!”
🔵🟡🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

Nice crossword! I like Santa and clefs. Plodded through to get or guess proper names from crossers but most clues ok. 
But Hallowe’en costumes sexy? Couldn’t get that one, didn’t try an ‘x’ in there! Not seen that. Only kids under about 10-11. 
Long live cultural differences!
Did anyone else happen to notice that Auntie Anne's new logo is just a plain pretzel? There's no ornamentation at all in the new version. This clue is already outdated!

While TESLA's birthday is indeed Serbian national science day, we unfortunately don't really celebrate and barely even acknowledge it. Not nearly as much as we should. 
But then again, as a Serbian scientist myself, I might be slightly biased.

I’m probably mistaken, but I thought I read somewhere that answers shouldn’t appear anywhere in the clues? 

(I was surprised to see answer 21D and clue 46D)

Many happy hours spent in the CVNP: biking along the towpath trail, X-C skiing at Virginia Kendall, hiking at the Ledges. I try to get back there at least once a year. So good to see it referenced in a clue.

Has CVNP ever been an entry, or it too niche?

Monday through Thursday, I, an experienced solver, savor the wit, verve, and skill in the puzzles, which are like delectable appetizers at a fine restaurant.  

Meanwhile, my excitement grows as it gets closer to the main event, that sweet challenge of Friday and Saturday capital-P Puzzles that make me think sideways, test my fortitude, entertain me with crackling wordplay, and reward me victories along the way.

I come into them wondering if they will simply give me an enjoyable taste or if they will be a beast of a feast, a Proper Friday, a Proper Saturday.

So, how about today?  Did it Friday properly?  Oh yes it did, IMO.  Riddles, so many delicious riddles – right from the start, with [One with an “accept all cookies” policy?].  Many answers that couldn’t be filled in due to vagueness, multiple possibilities, or out-of-wheelhouse.  Grins from wordplay, such as [Understudy opportunities?] and devilish clues like [Macronutrient grouping?].

Today’s box came with brow-furrowing areas that required many visits, countered by thrilling splat-fills cascading out of a single just-slapped-in answer.  With lovely answers, such as NO I INSIST, KIDS TABLE, and MERE MORTAL.  Interest all over the place in a low-word-count grid with nary a clunker.

Yes, Sarah and Rafael, you properly Fridayed today.  I left your creation beaming and satisfied, and dazzled by your skill.  Thank you so much for this!

I don't mind novelty but the insistence lately on adding small phrases in lieu of words is getting pretty old. NOIINSIST looks like an abomination and can almost only be cleaned with crosses, which, fine. But when half the answers are two word phrases it feels less clever and more ham fisted. Am I alone here?

Perfect Friday puzzle.

I pondered what a dentist would say for a while, and found the answer very funny -- why I'm not sure. Too bad that they no longer say this.  They use that vacuum gizmo instead.

Threw in the towel after struggling with the NW corner for too long, and glad I did.  Doubt I would have ever cracked it.  I knew that the cookies were not browser based but could not come up with the right name, forgot all about Daisies (I was in Dogpatch), no clue on APU and just dropped the ball on the vowel quintet.  

I will however pat myself on the back for figuring out the rest of this clever LIL beast.   Well played team.

I just wanted to take a moment to compliment Deb on her column today. You hit all the right notes, so—no notes.  As Andrzej demonstrated (somewhere below), I’m sure many of our non U.S. solvers appreciated it. 

If anyone has questions, sure, ask here. But definitely read the column first. Sam, Deb, and Caitlin do a great job.

great puzzle today, and outstanding column. one super nitpicky gripe 16D — a spec script - pitch is not a direct 1:1, not even the same thing. so, yeah, inside baseball, but the hint can be misleading.
Anyone who has been to a dentist in the last twenty years knows that you don’t spit anymore.

I found this to be easy for a Friday. Took me nearly ten minutes less than yesterday's (which I found rather difficult for a Thursday). No complaints from me as I prefer the type of solving where I can suss words out rather than having to look up references I have no clue about.

Another tough one for me, not sure whether to blame it on the persistent jet lag or merely an inability to get into the constructors wheelhouses. 12A a complete unknown; we have Rainbows, Brownies and Guides here. I only know the concept of Girl Scouts from American tv. 
Is GAL PAL an actual saying anywhere? I’ve never heard it used IRL, but then there are lots of things I haven’t come across that are perfectly legit.
Love the clue for SANTA, though it’s a mince pie and a carrot for Rudolph in our house.
I always chuckle at any clue for Northern English Town. It’s always LEEDS. Coming from one of the many, many other Northern towns between Manchester and York I feel I should put in a good word for them. Although, good luck finding words that mesh neatly with Cleckheaton or Heckmondwyke.

Very disappointed in this puzzle. OLIVIA RODRIGO is NOT the youngest artist to debut at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100; that honor goes to Stevie Wonder at age 13, followed my Peggy Marsh as age 15. Both debuted there in 1962. I had to actually go to a cheat page to get the puzzle answer, because it is so obviously wrong. I would opine on the rest of the puzzle, but having a bad clue/wrong answer put this one in trash for me, and I haven't finished it yet.

Gah, Thanksgiving's coming! They still make me sit at the KIDS TABLE with the goats. jk


Thanks for another fun one, constructors! Good 4 u

I had fun with this one but it took a long time. The NW was giving me fits because I instantly decided 21D [“Don’t embarrass me!”] was BE GOOD, which a parent might say, instead of BE COOL, more of an adolescent friend request . That enabled IDIOCY and BLIND DATES and on from there. Funny how things can fall into place quickly after even a small fix.

Today I was totally on the columnist’s wavelength. Loved and lived the tug-of-war analogy. Also, some of the same unknown answers:

Daisy troop - new to me (and cute as all get out - I’ve got a soon-to-be trooper-aged grand-daughter.)

Risqué (and other) makeup brands: new to me.

Idiocy - never heard of it.


> A fresh puzzle - some chew, but not too greully.

(Dumb?) Question for Deb Amlen:

Deb, if every time you use the acronym T. I. L. you then follow it with (Today I learned) why don't you just skip the T. I. L?  Either that or skip the explanation part and just assume we either remember it, or if a noob, that we will figure it out.  :)

Despite my nit picking, I do love your Wordplay columns!

Well, well, well...  I felt smart when ASTRONOMY filled in quickly (smirk, smirk) but the mess it created (esp with 13D) forced me to ignore Science and go with the IDIOCY instead.  

Other diversions:
STEP ON IT at 4D at 4D
BEHAVE...then BE GOOD...finally BE COOL (not something I've ever said to admonish anyone.  Just ask my kids.)
JAY before KAY.

Appreciated the gimme at 37A.  Got an Honorable Mention at a quilt show there... My first large quilt!  What a surprise! Especially since they had hung the quilt sideways...because it was so big.  Nice hiking trails, too.

I didn't know Google had a motto, let alone old and new versions.  And I don't care, even now.  

Given that the millions of Halloween costumes are devised and worn by *children* I think 18D is a perfect clue exemplifying The ICK Factor. Srsly???

I was completely mystified by TROOP, but Rex explained it.

Wonderful clues for EASY "A"S; ; ASTROLOGY; AEIOU; and ANTS.

It's amazing how quickly I, who never look at ads or watch commercials, remembered DON'T BE EVIL as Google's "former motto".  Could it be the unintended irony?  Not that I'm saying Google is EVIL, mind you, but it's not exactly the soul of beneficence either, IS IT?

A SEXY white sheet for a ghost?  A SEXY fright wig and hump for a witch?  SEXY bones for a skeleton?  I guess Halloween costumes have changed since I was a child, but I just don't see it.  I saw SEXY coming in at 18D, and said to the puzzle: "You're kidding me, right?"

Just what I want in a Friday themeless.  Good cluing, lively fill, and no junk.  Very enjoyable.
How do they know ants take naps?

I wonder what the likes of Richard Gere, Olivia Rodrigo and Cher think when they are keeping up their streak and realize the solve is their name or product? 

I can imagine that starting the day seeing your name as a test question for millions of people is an ego boost.  

I bet they don’t read the comments though.

Mark your calendars: today I knew the pop singer! Seriously, that "driving to the suburbs" song was unavoidable this summer. See, I have my clock radio set to a top 40 station, which normally gets me out of bed promptly, just to make it stop. But I would actually listen to that one if it came on, and occasionally "Antihero." Please don't take away my metalhead card.

My first thought, as far as young pop artists on Biilboard go, was Brenda Lee. Apparently I actually am older than dirt, or at least my taste in music is.
I got Olivia Rodrigo from having heard the name - wouldn't know her music if it bit me, though.
Good Friday workout. Thanks for the fun.

I enjoyed this one. The long crossers were generally familiar phrases, cleverly clued. I particularly liked the clues/answers for LIL and KIDSTABLE. The tug-of-war metaphor resonated with me, although I think of solving a tough puzzle more like looking for handholds on a climbing rock. Unlike others, TROOP was a good toehold for me as all three of my daughters were Daisies - good times, and I hope the organization is doing well!

Slowed down considerably by confidently filling in ASTROnOmY as "Field of stars" for the actual scientific field in question (and then of course having the majority of the crosses confirm the seemingly obviously-correct answer).
Having "cool" pull double duty as part of the grid and a clue felt, well... not cool. Did anyone else feel the same way? Or am I missing something?
Totally fell for tapas bar.
Right on, Deb Amlen. Great column today.
What would we do without the Usual Commenters telling we're wrong about everything?

Best part of NYT is refreshing myself to different definitions. STAFF: personnel, rod, and the one that I, as a musician, am kicking myself for not immediately realizing - musical. Good Friday puzzle.

I guess I should know better by now that even though I only fill in two answers on the first pass of the across and down clues, I am still very likely to attain the gold star.  Took 30% longer than average.  

Anyone who came up with the answer for "Macronutrient grouping?" without any crossings deserves an award (unless of course this clue has appeared before and they have a memory of steel).

After a nice easy Thursday this one was a challenge! Thought I was so cool because I got OLIVIA RODRIGO pretty quickly. But ended up spending a lot of time in the northwest corner at the end. I insist, I do insist, NO, I INSIST.

While Deb's tug-of-war description was very apt for my solving experience today, my favorite part of her comments was this:

"These differences are what make the comments on this column so interesting. We have so much to learn from one another if we remain kind to new solvers and they are open to new information."

I do find the differences very interesting and have learned so much from the more seasoned solvers out here in my year plus of puzzling, but I've also observed that many others do not seem to want to learn from them or others, nor are open to new information. Honestly, it's getting a bit tiresome. I appreciate Deb's wise words and hope we can heed them better. 

As for the puzzle, tough and enjoyable—though I can't remember the last time I had an Auntie Anne's pretzel or had a spit bowl at the dentist. I have read the comments and find it fascinating that others still have the spit sink. I assumed they had all gone the way of floppy discs and VCRs. As such, SPIT did not come quickly to me, but fear not, I wasn't just SPITting in the wind and eventually remembered that it was a thing after a cross or two.

Loved KIDSTABLE and EASYAS and SANTA. For some reason, I always enjoy the many misdirects for some sort of thieving. LOOTS fit the bill. 

Fun fact: Hollywood has the same number of letters as ASTROLOGY and ASTROnOmy! 

Probably shouldn't admit this but I only knew OHIO as clued (and I knew it immediately) because of my great fondness for Tommy Boy, the movie.
My favorite in a long time.  So many audible “ohs” or “hah”s coming from me.  Hard but doable.  Fell together nicely, very fun.
So, Santa does have a galpal, the song says so. " I saw mommy kissing Santa Claus."
I was expecting 35D to be BIERHALL since Oktoberfest is in the German spelling.
Superb puzzle. Had to take the usual Friday break to let my brain rest.  Came back and finished up the SW corner in seconds. Amazing how well that works. So proud! Such fun.

This was a tough one for me, and I am exhausted from working all morning at a local food bank, on a very cold and rainy day. I have an outside job there so came home soaked and chilled through. 
But I put on dry clothes, had a nice cup of tea and settled in to finish this excellent puzzle. It was a tough one, and I did have some look-up’s and some help from Deb. But I enjoyed it, and I’m grateful for this community. Some days I need the joy of being part of this community more than others. Thanks, Sarah and Rafael, Deb, and the whole puzzle team.
Understudy opportunities! The whole effort was worth that one. Great puzzle.
I should wear makeup more since 23A was unknown to me.

Loved this one. Can someone help me understand the “Macronutrient grouping?” wordplay? I understand the vowels AEIOU are what make the word “macronutrient” supervocalic, but how does that tie into the clue? 

When I finally solved this I thought perhaps the clue was going for “micronutrient grouping?” Because some of those letters correspond to vitamins of minerals… but if it’s macronutrient…? Huh?!

I know many of you have had streaks that have lasted hundreds or even thousands of days but I finally broke my eleven day streak and hit twelve.  The southwest corner almost broke me until I figured out BETRAY.  

Let's see if I can get through tomorrow and really extend the streak.

Macronutrient grouping? Say what??

Defeated by the NW corner.

@Steve L,

Thanks for mentioning the April 9, 2019 puzzle the other day. 

I just finished it and thought it was a lot of fun!  The note didn't appear on my phone app, which is where I did most of the puzzle so I feel good that I got it without the note hints. When I switched to my laptop to resume it later, the note appeared above it. I was glad I had missed it and also surprised it was there. Is it likely they added the note because it was a Tuesday not a Thursday? 

Anyhow, appreciated the mention of it. Otherwise, I'm working through 2023 archives but I enjoy checking out memorable ones from the comments.

I am aleays a little sad that there are brand names, now regarded as completely acceptable.  It may be in order to lure the young into crossward enthusiasm, but, if so, that is not a great commentary on what one thinks will appeal most to them.  This is my first and last complaint on the subject, I promise.

I just loved Deb's comment and I would like to put it down in needlepoint so I don't forget it

<>

What a lively crew today and lovely puzzle. 
Bon weekend, mes amis

I don't understand why, but lately i've found myself unable to break into most of the puzzles by my usual top/down or top across route.  but when i cry uncle andstart instead from the bottom right corner i'm in like flint.  this was another one of those but it was also one of the first in a while i couldn't finish, that top left corner just killed me.  i was pretty sure of the aeiou but i couldn't get past the daisies or santa and so stayed lost to staid.  the rest was a load of hard won fun

I would suggest that the answer to 13D Youngest artist to debut at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 should have been Stevie Wonder, who hit #1 at the age of 13, but I guess the key word of the clue is DEBUT.

I guess I'm showing my age.

Did anyone else get ART and DER instead of ACT and DEC? Be in the picture (frame) ART - end of cal.enDER.

So close to a gold star.
If OLIVIA RODRIGO is reading this, I like your music!

Fun one! It’s rare that I think that about a puzzle I can’t finish with my coffee before work in the morning, but coming back and looking at it with a fresh pair of eyes after dinner really made me appreciate it.

@Chungclan 

It's a crossword corset...a crosset?

Jonathan,

Are you referring to a clue in today's crossword? 
If so, which one? 



That is, if you haven't already deleted this app.

@Barry Ancona I did delete the app and cancel my subscription.  Macronutrients and Understudy Opportunities immediately come to mind.  The article explained for both essentially how much of a stretch it is.  When it isn’t these poor clues, it’s really obscure trivia.  I never had much trouble before the current editor took over.  Now it’s simply not enjoyable at all.

Jonathan,

Deb explains clues in some detail for newer solvers who may not get them at first glance (or even second or third glance).

Did you notice the question marks on those two clues? They aren't questions. That is a signal to expect some wordplay. And wordplay is what we do here.

I laughed at both clues and filled in the answers, as I'm sure thousands of other solvers will too.  Stick around a bit, and you might come to enjoy them too.

@Jonathan

I thought the understudy clue was exceptionally clever.  The macronutrients one not so much, but fair. In any case Deb was not saying they were too much of a stretch, just explaining them like she always does.
@Jonathan: I much prefer this style of clue, where you can 'aha' the meaning, to obscure proper names where you have no chance.

@Jonathan 

You don't like the "macronutrient" clue and wish Shortz were back.  But guess what?  You won't like it any better when Will returns. Here are some similar clues for AEIOU during Shortz's tenure:

Series of trade discounts  1/29/23
Ambidextrous feature?  1/8/23
Things found in wandering souls?  12/20/20
Succession within an ethnic group?  12/10/15
Facetious string?  2/8/15
Half-serious run?  9/16/06
You'll find them all in a tennis court  12/24/03

Every one of these clues employs a similar misdirection.

I'm afraid to say that if and when Mr. Shortz returns, you'll be truly disappointed.

PS I hope you understand that the "understudy" answer parses to EASY A'S.  I thought that was a brilliant clue.

PPS Deleting your app and canceling your subscription spites your own face.  You'll still be paying for puzzles you're studiously ignoring until your subscription period ends.

@Steve L 

The "understudy" clue for EASY A's is brilliant.

@Steve L I’m not complaining about today’s clue, but I prefer all of the ones you referenced (apart from the AMBIDEXTROUS one), because they all contain AEIOU in order. 🤓


.:.:.:.


 .:.:.


  .:.
@Barry Ancona always chiming in to defend the crossword gods. Lest anyone have a criticism he will make sure it doesn’t go unchallenged.
@N. Hornblower Agreed.
Funny that you guys are never around when I question or criticize "the crossword gods" (as I did most recently just yesterday).

@Barry Ancona 

You must have a much thicker skin than I do to keep coming back. 

Commenter A: “This clue makes no sense whatsoever! Fire Joel Fagliano!”

Barry Ancona: “This clue makes perfect sense because . . . .”

Commenter B: “There goes Barry, always defending the editors!”

Thanks for being here.
@Eric Hougland - Ditto that! I appreciate Barry's rebuttals to what are almost always invalid criticisms.

@sotto voce 

Thanks.

Also if you're new here, you can always expect a lecture from @Barry Ancona, singlehandedly enforcing the community standards.

C'mon, Barry - the puzzle is just a bit of fun. You don't have to lecture people.

@Fred 

If i may, i need to step in here to fact check.

@B 

American sandwich names seem so random to me as a European. If you showed an Italian your Italian sub, they'd be very, very surprised, and possibly a bit taken aback 🤣. I had to Google that sauce today, and when I did, it made zero sense. Caprese is a salad, not a sandwich, and it never includes pesto. European caprese, anyway.

@Andrzej 

Before I get stoned for the reply above: I don't think badly of your naming conventions. They are what they are, and they serve their purpose of informing Americans about their food, and all that food is part of American food culture. It's just that for a non-American the unfamiliar use of familiar terms is often confusing.

@Andrzej 

My favorite pub here in Las Vegas had a Caprese Salad on their menu (with pesto), but they also offered it as a sandwich, on sourdough bread. Alas, when the pandemic hit they scaled back their menu and both of them disappeared.

@Andrzej 

I agree with you on all points!  I have close family who are of Italian origin.  I've never heard of a "caprese sandwich" until this clue.  After solving I looked it up to confirm it's just a caprese salad on bread.  No pesto involved.

It might be some trendy naming thing the young constructors have seen?

@Jeb Jones 

Solving experiences are very individual - it is all about thinking in similar ways to the constructor, knowing the trivia, but also stuff like how you are feeling on a given day. For example, today I had problems with concentrating because I was stressed out over having to drive on fresh snow in my RWD car on summer tires, and without any safety systems.

I used to be annoyed by hard puzzles, but these days I no longer fret over them - but I do take joy in doing well, especially late in the week. I aced a Saturday puzzle in late August, one most solvers struggled with, and it felt great. Today's failure (of sorts) did not move me. It just happened.

The apostrophe- probably because I used to be a teacher. 
As a child in Scotland a long time ago Hallowe’en parties were centred around bobbing for apples   and ghosts and ghouls weren’t much involved. 
Children dressed in their parents old clothes and went ‘guising’ around the neighbours. But you had to sing a song or say a poem in order to get a sweetie/treat.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

My mom told me that, when she was young (late ‘30s, early ’40s), in her neighborhood (St. Albans, Queens, NY) the kids didn’t trick-or-treat on Halloween.  Instead, on Thanksgiving, they would dress as pilgrims and go door-to-door getting candy.

@Jane Wheelaghan

Us Polish people love our national heroes, and we worship them - without understanding why, exactly, and without trying to implement their life lessons in our own lives. @Bill

@Grant Good thing you're not constructing. Although the Cuyahoga had caught on fire at least 14 times, the last was in 1969--incidentally, both the Rouge River in Detroit and the Buffalo River had fires about the same time. Although nowhere as pristine waters as when the Iroquois massacred the Eries there, in the 18th c., the clean-up of the Cuyahoga has been one of the success stories of the EPA. Too bad it's likely to be dismantled by the hen-house foxes. "Cuyahoga" comes from Mohawk term, "crooked river"--the river runs in a broad U-shape, with the source further north than the mouth. But "burning river" does provide snappy monikers to local institutions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uDb9B0POknU

The vacuum gizmo is a cannula.

@Jamie S 
The key word in the clue is "debut." Stevie and Peggy reached number 1, but didn't debut at number 1.
@Jamie S Did Wonder's Fingertips debut at #1 or simply eventually reach #1.

@Jamie S yes Stevie Wonder’s “Fingertips Part 2” did hit #1 when he was 13 but it did not DEBUT at #1.  Before Billboard switched their chart tabulation methodology in 1991, there were zero records that debuted at #1.  To chart fanatics like me, the Soundscan Era that began 33 years ago is like the B.C.-A.D. changeover, or baseball’s Dead Ball era.  What used to be is statistically different now.

@Jamie S 

I'm guessing you don't understand how "debut" is being used.

They're not talking about the song being the artist's debut (first) song.

They're talking about an artist's song (not necessarily their first one) reaching #1 the first week it charts.  That's what "debut at #1" means.

In the case of a very young artist, it's more likely to be their first song, but doesn't have to be.

Hope this helps!

Grant,

@Amy 

In the age of streaming, it's much easier to debut at #1 than ever before, as you would see if you saw the list that was posted by someone else recently.  (Think of all the Swifties streaming a new song the minute it comes out.)  The number of debut #1's skyrocketed about 10 years ago.

Before that, radio plays were the driving factor.  And it was very hard to get hundreds of radio stations around the country to play a new song at the same time.  An artist had to already have a superstar reputation, and that works against very young artists.  Record sales were also factored into the charts back then, but record sales followed radio play, so they weren't that big a factor in this case.

Of course, you generally only buy a record once, but you can stream a song on repeat as many times as you want.

@Amy I'm older than dirt, too, and thought of Brenda Lee. But then, I looked up Peggy March who had the #1 hit "I Will Follow Him". She had just turned 15. https://www.billboard.com/pro/peggy-march-i-will-follow-him-interview/

@Antonio M. 

The "rule" you're thinking of is that any word in an entry cannot appear in its clue.  This doesn't mean it can't appear in a different clue.

Some people think this is inelegant.  But it's not a rule.

Could it have been avoided?  Probably.  But it didn't violate any rule.

Feel free to dislike it if you want.  Others will agree with you.  It doesn't bother me.

@Dave 

Probably get offended at something else.

I've got a suggestion.

No one will tell you you're wrong if you're actually not wrong.

Without your comment being a reply to something specific that set you off, it's hard to tell who or what you're miffed at.

But I will say that no one will correct you if you're already correct.  

Don't blame the puzzle because you don't understand the relation between the clue and the answer.

Don't blame the puzzle because you've never encountered a certain word or a certain meaning of a word.

Don't blame the puzzle because you don't know who OLIVIA RODRIGO (or anyone else) is.

Don't blame Joel Fagliano for a clue type that was common under Will Shortz, and you don't remember seeing it (in other words, you were fooled again).

Don't blame anyone because you don't like rebuses...especially when it's not Thursday or Sunday.

Remember that when you think something in the puzzle is wrong, it probably isn't.  Sometimes it is.  But not very often at all.

And understand that it's the general "you" I'm using, not you specifically.

Hope this helps!

HeathieJ,

I agree with your reflections on Deb’s comments. I also think it’s important (for comment regulars especially) to as much as possible recognize that it needs to be the constructor on the other end of your rope, not other commenters of whatever opinion. Don’t be distracted by someone yanking your chain, or a shiny hook in the water. You can’t usually “help” or “teach” someone who has just been miffed by a frustrating puzzle experience (whatever the cause), just like you can’t push a rope - okay, stretched this analogy too far :) 

That said, I personally enjoy and have learned a ton from all the regulars here, and encourage others (miffed or otherwise) to keep returning if you want to have fun with words in these puzzles.

@HeathieJ 

Well said!

I hope newer commenters will take Deb's and your wise words to heart and understand that the nature of this forum, a civil pow-wow, is unlike others on the internet which seem to be more like boxing rings with vitriol galore.

To those not yet familiar with the workings of this forum, please know that everone is welcome, but here we come to share, ask, help, discuss, learn, and laugh, with kindness and respect. And that's really not asking for much.

@jeffrey f 

I've done some construction (and had a few puzzles published), but I wouldn't call myself an experienced constructor. So take that into consideration.

Most constructors will get a grid they're satisfied with before they begin clueing in earnest. I expect that most start in the NW and work to the SE.

I find that the longer I've been working on clues, the less inspired I feel. There are lots of clue databases out there, and it's tempting to just pull a clue from one of them and reuse it or tweak it just a bit. And if you can't find a clue you like, you might use a thesaurus to find a clue.

So it may just be that the really tough clues — the ones that stretch your brain — tend to be clustered in the NW.

I finished the puzzle, but I spent almost as much time in the NW corner as in the rest of the grid.
